data.author: Adastra
data.content: Light Science Technologies (LST) is not a pure AgTech SaaS company, nor a lighting manufacturer in the traditional sense nor a passive- fire protection company. Its closest structural peers are integrated, IP-led systems suppliers rather than single-product vendors. LST’s hybrid model (manufacture + IP + data + compliance-driven markets) is harder to value but more resilient if executed properly. LST’s IP supports product families and upgrades, which is a prerequisite for repeat orders, retrofits and subscription data layers.  LST is building institutional trust before chasing valuation — a slow but compounding advantage. This is fundamental because risk is low relative to many AIM tech names because real revenue exists, multiple end markets exist and most importantly,  IP is not single-point-of-failure. In short, it' the profile of a company that frustrates short-term traders but rewards patient capital investment.
data.thread_title: Case for investment in a nutshell

data.author: Adastra
data.content: The original Government Building Safety Pledge was aimed at major developers committing to pay for or remediate unsafe cladding and other life-critical fire safety defects on residential buildings over 11 m tall that they built in the past 30 years. According to official government records, around 49 developers had signed the pledge (also referred to as the developer remediation contract) committing to fix unsafe buildings they developed or refurbished. Examples of signatories include: Barratt, Bellway, Berkeley Group, Crest Nicholson, Persimmon, Redrow, Taylor Wimpey and many others — 50+ major housebuilders across the sector. (This pledge is separate from other government remediation plans involving social landlords (which saw at least 110 social landlords sign a joint plan). Developers who signed up have agreed to identify buildings they developed that have life-critical fire safety defects (including unsafe cladding) and fund or carry out remediation. Those who failed to sign risk restrictions on their ability to operate (e.g., planning permissions and building control) until they comply. Its meant to protect leaseholders — so they are not left with the bills for safety fixes they had no role in creating. The pledge ensures the industry pays rather than leaseholders (in many cases) under schemes like the Cladding Safety Scheme or Building Safety Fund. It creates legal obligations and enforcement mechanisms if developers fail to act. There are thousands of buildings needing cladding remediation; as of late 2025, only about 35 % had completed works, and around 49 % had at least started remedial works. A significant number of buildings still haven’t been identified or assessed (government estimates suggest hundreds to potentially thousands remain to be fully catalogued). The Building Safety Pledge represents significant industry commitment to remediate dangerous cladding, but sheer scale, regulatory bottlenecks, legal complexities, backlog in approvals and data gaps mean remediation is still slow — much slower than early political statements implied. With most major firms signed up, practical delivery on the ground continues to lag a timeline many leaseholders hoped would be met sooner but latest information appears to indicate that the situation is now a priority issue and funding congestion is being speedily addressed. Hopefully this will be confirmed in next LST RNS.
data.thread_title: Funding congestion appears to be easing.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: I think your assessment is fair. The market isn’t being impatient; it’s applying a rational discount after several years where structure and pipeline visibility outpaced contracted scale. The share price reflects that history. What has changed is business quality. LST now has three coherent pillars, real revenue, granted IP, and exposure to regulated or regulation-adjacent markets where trust and provenance matter. CEM remains the low-margin base, AgTech is still early but technically validated, and Injectaclad is the high-margin option that could materially change group economics if it secures framework-level work. The case doesn’t rely on all pipelines converting — it relies on one clear proof point. Either a multi-site AgTech deployment or a Tier-1 PFP framework would be enough to reset risk perception and funding assumptions. Until then, the current discount is justified. In a risk-off market, that works both ways. Weaker stories are being purged, while businesses with real revenues, government-validated IP, and structural demand drivers are being ignored. That creates asymmetry: defined downside, with the potential for a sharp re-rating if a single scale signal lands. I think that signal is very close plus CEM could surprise on the defence contract side.
data.thread_title: RE: Case for investment in a nutshell

data.author: asimpleinvestor
data.content: I understand the focus on long-term timeframes, but the fundamentals eventually have to justify that patience. While it is true LST now has a clear three-pillar structure (CEM, AgTech, and PFP/Injectaclad), structure is merely a framework; the market prices the results that framework produces. The reality for long-term holders is a matter of record. From a 2021 IPO at 10p and peaks above 25p, the price currently sits around 4.25p. This represents a 60–80% erosion of capital for those in since the early days. Even for those who entered during the 2023/24 "flatline," the investment hasn't yet delivered a meaningful re-rating. CEM (UK Circuits): Still the engine room, providing 70.3% of Group revenue as of the H1 2025 results. While it’s diversifying into transport and medical sectors, it remains a lower-margin foundation. AgTech: Growing (revenue up to £0.5m in H1 25), but still represents a small fraction of the total business. The market is waiting for the £34m pipeline to move from "quoted" to "contracted." Injectaclad (PFP): This is the high-margin hope (64% gross margins). While we have seen RNS wins totalling £0.45m for hotel and school remediations recently, we haven't yet seen the Tier-1, multi-million-pound "rollout" that would justify a radical shift in valuation. To be fair, the maiden operating profit in H1 2025 was a step forward, but with a pre-tax loss of £0.16m and a history of fundraises, the "path to sustainability" is still being paved with shareholder dilution. If those significant contracts in the £58m pipeline finally land and the numbers move, the sentiment will shift. But until then, the market isn't being "impatient" it is applying a risk discount until the evidence of scale is undeniable.
data.thread_title: RE: Case for investment in a nutshell

data.author: asimpleinvestor
data.content: @Adastra The fundamentals don’t tally with your conclusion. A company only “rewards patient capital” when long‑term holders actually see value preserved or created. LST hasn’t delivered that. The share price has fallen from over 25p in 2021 to under 4p today a decline of almost 80% over four years. That isn’t rewarding patient investment; it’s eroding it. The hybrid model and IP story may sound compelling, but the market prices outcomes, not narratives. Until revenue growth, margins, cash position and contract conversion consistently improve, the idea that this is a slow‑burn compounding play is aspirational rather than evidence‑based. Short‑term traders aren’t the issue here, the long‑term trajectory simply hasn’t justified the thesis so far.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: Light Science Technologies (LST) is not a pure AgTech SaaS company, nor a lighting manufacturer in the traditional sense nor a passive- fire protection company. Its closest structural peers are integrated, IP-led systems suppliers rather than single-product vendors. LST’s hybrid model (manufacture + IP + data + compliance-driven markets) is harder to value but more resilient if executed properly. LST’s IP supports product families and upgrades, which is a prerequisite for repeat orders, retrofits and subscription data layers.  LST is building institutional trust before chasing valuation — a slow but compounding advantage. This is fundamental because risk is low relative to many AIM tech names because real revenue exists, multiple end markets exist and most importantly,  IP is not single-point-of-failure. In short, it' the profile of a company that frustrates short-term traders but rewards patient capital investment.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: The original Government Building Safety Pledge was aimed at major developers committing to pay for or remediate unsafe cladding and other life-critical fire safety defects on residential buildings over 11 m tall that they built in the past 30 years. According to official government records, around 49 developers had signed the pledge (also referred to as the developer remediation contract) committing to fix unsafe buildings they developed or refurbished. Examples of signatories include: Barratt, Bellway, Berkeley Group, Crest Nicholson, Persimmon, Redrow, Taylor Wimpey and many others — 50+ major housebuilders across the sector. (This pledge is separate from other government remediation plans involving social landlords (which saw at least 110 social landlords sign a joint plan). Developers who signed up have agreed to identify buildings they developed that have life-critical fire safety defects (including unsafe cladding) and fund or carry out remediation. Those who failed to sign risk restrictions on their ability to operate (e.g., planning permissions and building control) until they comply. Its meant to protect leaseholders — so they are not left with the bills for safety fixes they had no role in creating. The pledge ensures the industry pays rather than leaseholders (in many cases) under schemes like the Cladding Safety Scheme or Building Safety Fund. It creates legal obligations and enforcement mechanisms if developers fail to act. There are thousands of buildings needing cladding remediation; as of late 2025, only about 35 % had completed works, and around 49 % had at least started remedial works. A significant number of buildings still haven’t been identified or assessed (government estimates suggest hundreds to potentially thousands remain to be fully catalogued). The Building Safety Pledge represents significant industry commitment to remediate dangerous cladding, but sheer scale, regulatory bottlenecks, legal complexities, backlog in approvals and data gaps mean remediation is still slow — much slower than early political statements implied. With most major firms signed up, practical delivery on the ground continues to lag a timeline many leaseholders hoped would be met sooner but latest information appears to indicate that the situation is now a priority issue and funding congestion is being speedily addressed. Hopefully this will be confirmed in next LST RNS.

Given that PFP work is very CapEx light, it should have a big effect on the bottom line. The other two divisions are also in similar positions regarding inflection points. Interesting year ahead.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: I think your assessment is fair. The market isn’t being impatient; it’s applying a rational discount after several years where structure and pipeline visibility outpaced contracted scale. The share price reflects that history. What has changed is business quality. LST now has three coherent pillars, real revenue, granted IP, and exposure to regulated or regulation-adjacent markets where trust and provenance matter. CEM remains the low-margin base, AgTech is still early but technically validated, and Injectaclad is the high-margin option that could materially change group economics if it secures framework-level work. The case doesn’t rely on all pipelines converting — it relies on one clear proof point. Either a multi-site AgTech deployment or a Tier-1 PFP framework would be enough to reset risk perception and funding assumptions. Until then, the current discount is justified. In a risk-off market, that works both ways. Weaker stories are being purged, while businesses with real revenues, government-validated IP, and structural demand drivers are being ignored. That creates asymmetry: defined downside, with the potential for a sharp re-rating if a single scale signal lands. I think that signal is very close plus CEM could surprise on the defence contract side.
data.thread_title: RE: Case for investment in a nutshell

data.author: asimpleinvestor
data.content: I understand the focus on long-term timeframes, but the fundamentals eventually have to justify that patience. While it is true LST now has a clear three-pillar structure (CEM, AgTech, and PFP/Injectaclad), structure is merely a framework; the market prices the results that framework produces. The reality for long-term holders is a matter of record. From a 2021 IPO at 10p and peaks above 25p, the price currently sits around 4.25p. This represents a 60–80% erosion of capital for those in since the early days. Even for those who entered during the 2023/24 "flatline," the investment hasn't yet delivered a meaningful re-rating. CEM (UK Circuits): Still the engine room, providing 70.3% of Group revenue as of the H1 2025 results. While it’s diversifying into transport and medical sectors, it remains a lower-margin foundation. AgTech: Growing (revenue up to £0.5m in H1 25), but still represents a small fraction of the total business. The market is waiting for the £34m pipeline to move from "quoted" to "contracted." Injectaclad (PFP): This is the high-margin hope (64% gross margins). While we have seen RNS wins totalling £0.45m for hotel and school remediations recently, we haven't yet seen the Tier-1, multi-million-pound "rollout" that would justify a radical shift in valuation. To be fair, the maiden operating profit in H1 2025 was a step forward, but with a pre-tax loss of £0.16m and a history of fundraises, the "path to sustainability" is still being paved with shareholder dilution. If those significant contracts in the £58m pipeline finally land and the numbers move, the sentiment will shift. But until then, the market isn't being "impatient" it is applying a risk discount until the evidence of scale is undeniable.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: Light Science Technologies (LST) is not a pure AgTech SaaS company, nor a lighting manufacturer in the traditional sense nor a passive- fire protection company. Its closest structural peers are integrated, IP-led systems suppliers rather than single-product vendors. LST’s hybrid model (manufacture + IP + data + compliance-driven markets) is harder to value but more resilient if executed properly. LST’s IP supports product families and upgrades, which is a prerequisite for repeat orders, retrofits and subscription data layers.  LST is building institutional trust before chasing valuation — a slow but compounding advantage. This is fundamental because risk is low relative to many AIM tech names because real revenue exists, multiple end markets exist and most importantly,  IP is not single-point-of-failure. In short, it' the profile of a company that frustrates short-term traders but rewards patient capital investment.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: The original Government Building Safety Pledge was aimed at major developers committing to pay for or remediate unsafe cladding and other life-critical fire safety defects on residential buildings over 11 m tall that they built in the past 30 years. According to official government records, around 49 developers had signed the pledge (also referred to as the developer remediation contract) committing to fix unsafe buildings they developed or refurbished. Examples of signatories include: Barratt, Bellway, Berkeley Group, Crest Nicholson, Persimmon, Redrow, Taylor Wimpey and many others — 50+ major housebuilders across the sector. (This pledge is separate from other government remediation plans involving social landlords (which saw at least 110 social landlords sign a joint plan). Developers who signed up have agreed to identify buildings they developed that have life-critical fire safety defects (including unsafe cladding) and fund or carry out remediation. Those who failed to sign risk restrictions on their ability to operate (e.g., planning permissions and building control) until they comply. Its meant to protect leaseholders — so they are not left with the bills for safety fixes they had no role in creating. The pledge ensures the industry pays rather than leaseholders (in many cases) under schemes like the Cladding Safety Scheme or Building Safety Fund. It creates legal obligations and enforcement mechanisms if developers fail to act. There are thousands of buildings needing cladding remediation; as of late 2025, only about 35 % had completed works, and around 49 % had at least started remedial works. A significant number of buildings still haven’t been identified or assessed (government estimates suggest hundreds to potentially thousands remain to be fully catalogued). The Building Safety Pledge represents significant industry commitment to remediate dangerous cladding, but sheer scale, regulatory bottlenecks, legal complexities, backlog in approvals and data gaps mean remediation is still slow — much slower than early political statements implied. With most major firms signed up, practical delivery on the ground continues to lag a timeline many leaseholders hoped would be met sooner but latest information appears to indicate that the situation is now a priority issue and funding congestion is being speedily addressed. Hopefully this will be confirmed in next LST RNS.

I suspect the next RNS will confirm those decisions (big companies move slowly but government pressure is there). Once those contracts are cemented then momentum should rapidly increase. Given that PFP work is very CapEx light, it should have a big effect on the bottom line. The other two divisions are also in similar positions regarding inflection points. Interesting year ahead.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: I think your assessment is fair. The market isn’t being impatient; it’s applying a rational discount after several years where structure and pipeline visibility outpaced contracted scale. The share price reflects that history. What has changed is business quality. LST now has three coherent pillars, real revenue, granted IP, and exposure to regulated or regulation-adjacent markets where trust and provenance matter. CEM remains the low-margin base, AgTech is still early but technically validated, and Injectaclad is the high-margin option that could materially change group economics if it secures framework-level work. The case doesn’t rely on all pipelines converting — it relies on one clear proof point. Either a multi-site AgTech deployment or a Tier-1 PFP framework would be enough to reset risk perception and funding assumptions. Until then, the current discount is justified. In a risk-off market, that works both ways. Weaker stories are being purged, while businesses with real revenues, government-validated IP, and structural demand drivers are being ignored. That creates asymmetry: defined downside, with the potential for a sharp re-rating if a single scale signal lands. I think that signal is very close plus CEM could surprise on the defence contract side.
data.thread_title: RE: Case for investment in a nutshell

data.author: asimpleinvestor
data.content: I understand the focus on long-term timeframes, but the fundamentals eventually have to justify that patience. While it is true LST now has a clear three-pillar structure (CEM, AgTech, and PFP/Injectaclad), structure is merely a framework; the market prices the results that framework produces. The reality for long-term holders is a matter of record. From a 2021 IPO at 10p and peaks above 25p, the price currently sits around 4.25p. This represents a 60–80% erosion of capital for those in since the early days. Even for those who entered during the 2023/24 "flatline," the investment hasn't yet delivered a meaningful re-rating. CEM (UK Circuits): Still the engine room, providing 70.3% of Group revenue as of the H1 2025 results. While it’s diversifying into transport and medical sectors, it remains a lower-margin foundation. AgTech: Growing (revenue up to £0.5m in H1 25), but still represents a small fraction of the total business. The market is waiting for the £34m pipeline to move from "quoted" to "contracted." Injectaclad (PFP): This is the high-margin hope (64% gross margins). While we have seen RNS wins totalling £0.45m for hotel and school remediations recently, we haven't yet seen the Tier-1, multi-million-pound "rollout" that would justify a radical shift in valuation. To be fair, the maiden operating profit in H1 2025 was a step forward, but with a pre-tax loss of £0.16m and a history of fundraises, the "path to sustainability" is still being paved with shareholder dilution. If those significant contracts in the £58m pipeline finally land and the numbers move, the sentiment will shift. But until then, the market isn't being "impatient" it is applying a risk discount until the evidence of scale is undeniable.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: On so many fundamentals this should easily double in 2026. Do the research and look at the interim statements: PFP revenues in the Period grew significantly to £1.0m (H1 2024: £0.3m), with average gross margins increased to 64.3% (H1 2024: 41.2%). AGT revenues grew to £0.5m (H1 2024: £0.4m), with average gross margins of 42.0% (H1 2024: 48.4%) and CEM generated revenues of £3.6m (H1 2024: £4.5m). Importantly, CEM achieved gross margins of 27.8% (H1 2024: 23.7%), as the sales mix was more diverse and targeted. This resulted in an increased Group gross profit margin of 36.3% for the Period, up considerably from 26.6% in the first six months of 2024 and up from 30.3% for the 2024 full year. Clearly CEM is the arm that was underperforming due to various factors. That is being fully addressed with multiple engagements focussed on the desire of UK industries to increasingly onshore, particularly in defence. Margins in the other two businesses are excellent so progress should be swift. Good time to board the train imo if not already invested and increasing.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: Light Science Technologies (LST) is not a pure AgTech SaaS company, nor a lighting manufacturer in the traditional sense nor a passive- fire protection company. Its closest structural peers are integrated, IP-led systems suppliers rather than single-product vendors. LST’s hybrid model (manufacture + IP + data + compliance-driven markets) is harder to value but more resilient if executed properly. LST’s IP supports product families and upgrades, which is a prerequisite for repeat orders, retrofits and subscription data layers.  LST is building institutional trust before chasing valuation — a slow but compounding advantage. This is fundamental because risk is low relative to many AIM tech names because real revenue exists, multiple end markets exist and most importantly,  IP is not single-point-of-failure. In short, it' the profile of a company that frustrates short-term traders but rewards patient capital investment.

data.author: Adastra
data.content: The original Government Building Safety Pledge was aimed at major developers committing to pay for or remediate unsafe cladding and other life-critical fire safety defects on residential buildings over 11 m tall that they built in the past 30 years. According to official government records, around 49 developers had signed the pledge (also referred to as the developer remediation contract) committing to fix unsafe buildings they developed or refurbished. Examples of signatories include: Barratt, Bellway, Berkeley Group, Crest Nicholson, Persimmon, Redrow, Taylor Wimpey and many others — 50+ major housebuilders across the sector. (This pledge is separate from other government remediation plans involving social landlords (which saw at least 110 social landlords sign a joint plan). Developers who signed up have agreed to identify buildings they developed that have life-critical fire safety defects (including unsafe cladding) and fund or carry out remediation. Those who failed to sign risk restrictions on their ability to operate (e.g., planning permissions and building control) until they comply. Its meant to protect leaseholders — so they are not left with the bills for safety fixes they had no role in creating. The pledge ensures the industry pays rather than leaseholders (in many cases) under schemes like the Cladding Safety Scheme or Building Safety Fund. It creates legal obligations and enforcement mechanisms if developers fail to act. There are thousands of buildings needing cladding remediation; as of late 2025, only about 35 % had completed works, and around 49 % had at least started remedial works. A significant number of buildings still haven’t been identified or assessed (government estimates suggest hundreds to potentially thousands remain to be fully catalogued). The Building Safety Pledge represents significant industry commitment to remediate dangerous cladding, but sheer scale, regulatory bottlenecks, legal complexities, backlog in approvals and data gaps mean remediation is still slow — much slower than early political statements implied. With most major firms signed up, practical delivery on the ground continues to lag a timeline many leaseholders hoped would be met sooner but latest information appears to indicate that the situation is now a priority issue and funding congestion is being speedily addressed. Hopefully this will be confirmed in next LST RNS.

Initial projects have been carried out by LST's PFP Injectaclad division and roll-outs should be in hand. Big decisions and release of funding should be happening as we enter 2026. I suspect the next RNS will confirm those decisions (big companies move slowly but government pressure is there). Once those contracts are cemented then momentum should rapidly increase. Given that PFP work is very CapEx light, it should have a big effect on the bottom line. The other two divisions are also in similar positions regarding inflection points. Interesting year ahead.
